column1: This course provides an overview of basic concepts and theories of learning sciences.First, concepts and theories of cognitive psychology related to learning are introduced, including but not limited to attention, language processing, working memory, long-term memory, meaningful learning, constructivism, knowledge representation, memory processes of encoding, retrieval, and forgetting.Second, evidence-based instructional strategies and principles based on research in learning sciences are discussed, such as attention/memory training, flipped classroom, speed reading, learning styles, game-based learning, feedback, worked examples, spacing and interleaving, influence of mood and anxiety, metacognition and self-regulation, and practice testing.

This course aims to discuss what, why and how learning design elements can/ should be incorporated in learning environments to support effective learning in new and emerging educational contexts. Particularly, the focus of the course will be on examining the integration of learning design principles and approaches in accordance with the educational goals of the twenty-first century.

Analysis of learner data provides valuable insight into learning processes to understand and optimize learning environments. This enables universities, schools, and training organizations to improve the quality and overall efficiency of learning. This course will provide an introduction to analytics in learning and how it is being deployed in various contexts in education, including to inform educators, and to promote scientific discovery. Students will explore the logic of analytics, the basics of cleaning and using educational data, context analysis, and predictive models. This course will also discuss tools and analytics methods that educators need, and how to protect learner privacy and other rights.

Design thinking as scientific inquiry is an innovative approach for developing user-centered innovative solutions in business and society. This course will discuss design thinking principles such as user participation, problem framing, prototype making, experimentation and evaluation, visualization and diversity, which are essential skills for management and innovation. It will also discuss how design thinking drives innovation and solves some of the most global and local complex problems, for example, develop new product/service development, and address strategic, operational, organizational and social issues. Upon completion, students are able to apply design thinking to their own situations and organizations, and plan for how to embed this type of thinking to drive innovation.

A digital citizen is a person who develops the skills, literacy, competence to safely and effectively use the internet and digital technologies. It plays a powerful role in facilitating people learn, connect, engage with their community, and create more promising futures. This course will discuss competencies of digital citizenship such as digital literacy, artificial intelligence literacy, media literacy, and computational thinking. Students will design, develop, and evaluate a digital citizenship program is used by individuals, nonprofits, schools, and governments all over the world.

Educational technologies improve teaching and learning through the application of educational technologies used in K-12 schools, higher education institutions, corporations, organizations, associations, governments and foundation. Their implementation and sustainability are crucial to their efficiencies. This course will discuss different related theories and models to promote educational technology. Students will recognize how to introduce and sustain educational technologies in the communities.

This course aims to provide a broad understanding of the importance of innovation to organizations and the role of innovative leadership in the contemporary society. Various types of innovation and models of organizations and leadership will be explored to elucidate their inter-relationships. Students will have an opportunity to examine the characteristics of innovative learning organizations with real-life examples including the organizational structure, culture and leadership strategies for organizational change. Key processes of organizational learning, teamwork, strategic development and knowledge management will be analyzed in specific contexts. Through reviewing a range of literature and applying it to multiple scenarios, students are encouraged to integrate theory with practice and develop their leadership capacity for driving innovation in different organizational settings.

This course is a form of experiential learning, which provides opportunities for students to put the knowledge and skills they have learned from the programme into practice via engaging in a real-life career in the learning design and technology industry. Areas of industry attachment include technology companies, e-learning service providers, training and development companies, universities, schools, libraries and governmental organizations. Students are expected to carry out their responsibilities as if they are full-time employees of the industry they are attached to. Evaluation of student performance will be based on multiple sources, such as participation in tutorials, internship performance, the internship report, and evaluation by the industry supervisor.

This course aims to provide an overview on various research methods (qualitative, quantitative and mixed methods) used in educational research and prepare students to conduct their own research project. The course will go through the steps in designing research topic and questions, searching and reviewing relevant literature, formulating research hypotheses, identifying suitable research tools and sampling methods, analyzing and interpreting research findings and writing up research reports with students. Students will also learn the principles of research ethics and procedures in obtaining ethics clearance at CUHK.

Educational innovation can be found in processes, services, programmes and partnerships. Educational innovation improves teaching and learning, enhances wellbeing, ensures successful transitions and pathways, as well as alleviates inequity. This course will start with an introduction on the role of education in economic development followed by discussion on various forms of educational innovation in schooling systems including alternative schools. Case studies on innovative educational practice in different countries will be examined. Students will be asked to identify educational challenges that learners and teachers are grappling with. Guest lectures are offered by leaders of local or international social enterprises and foundations that practice and support educational innovations. Students will be invited to brainstorm and join social enterprises’ efforts to provide sustainable strategies to tackle development issues especially to that of educational equality. Evaluation on how educational innovations promote student learning will also be explored. At the end of the course, students will develop a proposal that advances current educational practices in our society reflecting community needs and addressing the social inequality and poverty issues.

This course provides an introductory survey of the links between education, technological advancement and human development in the globe. While digital and technological innovation accelerates economic growth and plays a critical role for reducing poverty, it also trigger social inequality issues. Further, technological changes (such as computerization, artificial intelligence, etc.) will fundamentally alter the nature of professions and of high skilled jobs generally. The course starts with an overview of the current educational attainment and schooling investments across the world. This is followed by exploring the demand for human capital and educational investments aligned with economic development, public financing of education. Students will also be able to examine interactions between education, technology and development from social and economic perspectives on other issues, including compulsory education reform, manpower planning and curriculum reform, automation and its impact on jobs and labor market, gender gap in schooling and STEM subjects, welfare policy reforms and its impact on children.

This course aims to provide students with fundamental knowledge of selected areas of special needs (learning disabilities, autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit / hyperactivity disorder, emotional and behavioral disorder, and giftedness) and help them to understand possible learning difficulties children with these special needs would encounter. For each kind of special need, students will learn its characteristics, causes, and provision of special education in Hong Kong. Besides, this course will also prepare students for designing effective solutions using technology for children with learning, literacy, and cognitive challenges.

This is a two-semester course for final year students of the programme. Under the guidance of project supervisors, students are required to complete an individual project pertaining to the applications of learning, design, and technology in education, workplace, or other organizational settings. They should draw on theoretically-informed and empirically-validated learning design frameworks to design innovative and authentic technology-enriched learning experiences for the participants so that the curricular goals are attained. They should propose a project in the field of Learning Design and Technology and execute that project from analysis to evaluation.
